meanings.def: to jump high or a long way
examples: + adv./prep. A dolphin leapt out of the water.
We leaped over the stream.
leap something The horse leapt a five-foot wall.
She leaped across the puddles.
She leaped clear of the water.
The horse leaped over high fences.
A dolphin suddenly leapt out of the water.
The horse galloped on, leaping fences and hedges as it came to them.

meanings.def: to move or do something suddenly and quickly
examples: She leapt out of bed.
He leaped across the room to answer the door.
I leapt to my feet (= stood up quickly).
They leapt into action immediately.
(figurative) She was quick to leap to my defence (= speak in support of me).
The photo seemed to leap off the page (= it got your attention immediately).
His name leapt out at me (= I saw it immediately).
Don't be so nervous—anyone would think I was about to leap on you.
He almost leaped down the stairs when he heard who it was.
He leaped down from the ladder and ran over to her.
He leapt onto his horse and rode off.
He leapt out of bed when he heard the telephone.
Rose immediately leapt to her feet.
children leaping about with excitement
The people on the shore were leaping up and down and shouting.

meanings.def: to increase suddenly and by a large amount
examples: The shares leapt in value from 476p to close at 536p.
The company saw pre-tax profits leap to £14.5 million in 2004.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody has a sudden feeling of happiness or excitement
examples: My heart leapt at the news.
Her heart leaped with joy.

meanings.def: to make a decision about somebody/something too quickly, before you know or have thought about all the facts
examples: There I go again—jumping to conclusions.
Don't jump to conclusions.
We don't want to jump to the wrong conclusion.

meanings.def: used to advise somebody to think about the possible results or dangers of something before doing it

idioms.def: used to say that somebody has a sudden feeling of happiness or excitement
examples: My heart leapt at the news.
Her heart leaped with joy.

idioms.idiom: jump/leap to conclusions | jump/leap to the conclusion that…
idioms.def: to make a decision about somebody/something too quickly, before you know or have thought about all the facts
examples: There I go again—jumping to conclusions.
Don't jump to conclusions.
We don't want to jump to the wrong conclusion.

idioms.def: used to advise somebody to think about the possible results or dangers of something before doing it

examples: a leap of six metres
She took a flying leap and landed on the other side of the stream.
He made a flying leap at the ball.
(figurative) His heart gave a sudden leap when he saw her.

meanings.def: a sudden large increase in something
examples: a leap in profits
leap in something a leap in prices
a dramatic leap in the number of people out of work
leap (from something) (to something) a leap from $632 to $735

meanings.def: a sudden change from one thing to another; very fast progress with something
examples: Few people successfully make the leap from television to the movies.
a great leap into the unknown
They've made a great leap forward with their building in the last few years.
Her health has improved in leaps and bounds.
His technique has come on in leaps and bounds this season.

meanings.def: an action or a risk that you take without knowing anything about the activity or what the result will be
examples: I didn’t know what the new job would be like—I just took a leap in the dark.

meanings.def: a belief in something that is not known or has not been done before
examples: These reforms are totally untested and will require a leap of faith on the part of teachers.
Her health has improved in leaps and bounds.
His technique has come on in leaps and bounds this season.

idioms.def: an action or a risk that you take without knowing anything about the activity or what the result will be
examples: I didn’t know what the new job would be like—I just took a leap in the dark.

idioms.def: a belief in something that is not known or has not been done before
examples: These reforms are totally untested and will require a leap of faith on the part of teachers.
